QUINOLONES

  • Drugs in class

Advice when patient is pregnant

With intravenous use or oral use

Avoid in pregnancy—shown to cause arthropathy in animal studies; safer alternatives are available.

Contra indications

Known side effects

Specific side effects

commonOrVeryCommon: diarrhoea, dizziness, headache, nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, dizziness, headache, nausea, vomiting,

uncommon: abdominal pain, anorexia, anxiety, arthralgia, asthenia, blood disorders, confusion, depression, disturbances in taste, disturbances in vision, dyspepsia, eosinophilia, hallucinations, leucopenia, myalgia, rash, sleep disturbances, thrombocytopenia, tremor, abdominal pain, anorexia, anxiety, arthralgia, asthenia, blood disorders, confusion, depression, disturbances in taste, disturbances in vision, dyspepsia, eosinophilia, hallucinations, leucopenia, myalgia, rash, sleep disturbances, thrombocytopenia, tremor,

rare: antibiotic-associated colitis, convulsions, disturbances in hearing, disturbances in smell, dyspnoea, hepatic dysfunction, hepatitis, hypotension, interstitial nephritis, jaundice, photosensitivity, psychoses, renal failure, symptoms of peripheral neuropathy (sometimes irreversible), tendon damage, tendon inflammation, vasculitis, antibiotic-associated colitis, convulsions, disturbances in hearing, disturbances in smell, dyspnoea, hepatic dysfunction, hepatitis, hypotension, interstitial nephritis, jaundice, photosensitivity, psychoses, renal failure, symptoms of peripheral neuropathy (sometimes irreversible), tendon damage, tendon inflammation, vasculitis,

veryRare: Stevens-Johnson syndrome, toxic epidermal necrolysis, Stevens-Johnson syndrome, toxic epidermal necrolysis,

The drug should be discontinued if psychiatric, neurological, or hypersensitivity reactions (including severe rash) occur.

Important safety information

With intravenous use or oral use

The CSM has warned that quinolones may induce convulsions in patients with or without a history of convulsions; taking NSAIDs at the same time may also induce them.

With intravenous use or oral use

Tendon damage

Tendon damage (including rupture) has been reported rarely in patients receiving quinolones. Tendon rupture may occur within 48 hours of starting treatment; cases have also been reported several months after stopping a quinolone. Healthcare professionals are reminded that:

  • quinolones are contra-indicated in patients with a history of tendon disorders related to quinolone use;
  • patients over 60 years of age are more prone to tendon damage;
  • the risk of tendon damage is increased by the concomitant use of corticosteroids;
  • if tendinitis is suspected, the quinolone should be discontinued immediately.

Cautions regarding administration

  • With intravenous use: can prolong the QT interval
  • With intravenous use: conditions that predispose to seizures
  • With intravenous use: exposure to excessive sunlight should be avoided (discontinue if photosensitivity occurs)
  • With intravenous use: G6PD deficiency
  • With intravenous use: history of epilepsy
  • With intravenous use: myasthenia gravis (risk of exacerbation)
  • With oral use: can prolong the QT interval
  • With oral use: conditions that predispose to seizures
  • With oral use: exposure to excessive sunlight should be avoided (discontinue if photosensitivity occurs)
  • With oral use: G6PD deficiency
  • With oral use: history of epilepsy
  • With oral use: myasthenia gravis (risk of exacerbation)

Advice regarding allergies and cross sensitivities

Use of quinolones contraindicated in quinolone hypersensitivity.

Drugs in the class of QUINOLONES

  • CIPROFLOXACIN
  • LEVOFLOXACIN
  • MOXIFLOXACIN
  • NALIDIXIC ACID
  • NORFLOXACIN
  • OFLOXACIN
